title: 106_s1346
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Office of Advocacy Act". Congress recognizes the burden of excessive regulations on small businesses and the reluctance of Federal agencies to comply with regulatory requirements. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is seen as an effective advocate for small businesses, needing independence and sufficient resources to fulfill its role. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration requires independence and adequate resources to assess the impact of regulations on small businesses effectively. Its research and expertise are valuable to both Congress and executive branch agencies. The purposes of this Act are to ensure the Office of Advocacy has independence and resources to advocate for small businesses, report to Congress on issues affecting small businesses, provide separate funding authorization, monitor agency compliance with regulations, and enhance its role. SEC. 4. OFFICE OF ADVOCACY. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section, SEC. 32, establishing the Office of Advocacy. The Office of Advocacy, established under SEC. 32 of the Small Business Act, includes the Chief Counsel for Advocacy appointed by the President. The Chief Counsel must be appointed from civilian life, without political affiliation, and cannot have served in the Small Business Administration for five years prior. The Office of Advocacy, established under the Small Business Act, examines the role of small businesses in the US economy and their contributions to competition, economic mobility, inflation control, production, employment, productivity, exports, innovation, and entrepreneurship. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy may be removed by the President with notification to Congress. Each appropriation request by the Administration must include a separate request for the Office. The curr_chunk discusses spurring production, expanding employment opportunities, increasing productivity, promoting exports, stimulating innovation and entrepreneurship, assessing Federal subsidy programs for small businesses, measuring the effects of government regulation, determining the impact of the tax structure on small businesses, and proposing changes to enable small businesses to contribute to the economy. The curr_chunk focuses on proposals to alter the tax structure for small businesses to enhance their contribution to the economy. It includes studying financial markets' ability to meet small business credit needs, evaluating government impact on credit, recommending methods for financial resource availability, and assessing efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises. The curr_chunk focuses on recommendations to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, strengthen small businesses, create a competitive business environment, define small businesses, and address issues affecting small businesses through reports and recommendations to relevant authorities. The Office shall serve as a focal point for complaints, counsel small businesses, develop proposals for policy changes, represent small businesses' interests, and seek cooperation from the public and other agencies. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy coordinates with other Federal agencies, enlists cooperation from public and private entities to disseminate information beneficial to small businesses, and appoints necessary personnel to carry out its duties. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy appoints personnel without following certain provisions of the United States Code, with compensation not exceeding GS-15 rates. The Chief Counsel has powers to procure services and consult with experts in relevant fields. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy appoints personnel and advisory boards, holds hearings, and receives administrative support as necessary. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy appoints personnel and advisory boards, holds hearings, and receives administrative support such as office space, equipment, and information from federal agencies as needed. Annual reports are submitted to the President and relevant committees. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy submits annual reports to the President and relevant committees on agency compliance with title 5, United States Code. The Chief Counsel is authorized to prepare additional reports as deemed necessary, with appropriations authorized for each fiscal year. No report can be submitted to any other federal department or agency before being submitted to the President and Congress. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy is authorized to receive necessary appropriations each fiscal year. Any funds appropriated shall remain available until expended. Title II of Public Law 94-305 is repealed. The incumbent Chief Counsel for Advocacy will continue to serve in their position according to the Small Business Act. The Senate passed the bill on November 5, 1999. Attest: GARY SISCO, Secretary.
